description: Repeated authentication success for the same user (samantha.thornton) from the same IP may indicate use of valid credentials in an automated or scripted fashion.
Another identical successful login for samantha.thornton from same IP immediately after the previous, suggesting scripted or persistent access.
Log duplication from a different log source (syslog vs mail.log) showing same session, not a unique event.
Additional Dovecot success log showing same login parameters, likely from a separate log file but not a unique login event.
Repeated log from another syslog entry â€” still not a new login, showing same session.
New login event for same user with different session ID and timestamp, showing persistent or repeated access attempts.
Duplicate log entry for same login session ID, most likely from separate log source (mail.log).
Third instance of same login session, logged in syslog again. Not a separate event.
Routine ClamAV signature update, not indicative of malicious activity.
Successful Dovecot login for a different user (damian.jordan), possible persistence mechanism via valid credentials.
Successful IMAP login for user 'damian.jordan' using PLAIN authentication from same IP address repeatedly, possibly indicating misuse of valid credentials.
Repeated login success for the same user in short time may suggest automated usage or persistence using valid credentials.
Multiple entries for successful logins within the same second using the same credentials implies automated access using stolen credentials.
Identical session data seen across logs implies reuse or abuse of valid account credentials over multiple log sources.
Same user, same IP, same session across different log files suggests this is duplicated log entries, not separate events.
Same credentials and IP used with slight variations in session, may suggest legitimate user or scripted persistent access.
Another duplicate entry for the same session indicates possible redundancy in log ingestion, not a new event.
Repeated appearance of same session ID points to multiple system logs reporting the same successful login event.
New session ID and process ID for same user and IP indicate fresh login activity, potentially indicating session cycling.
Matching entry to previous one in different log file suggests it's the same login event being captured again.
Successful login via Dovecot IMAP using a valid user account (damian.jordan); might indicate lateral movement or persistence if the account was compromised.
SSH authentication succeeded for user 'phopkins' from external IP using a public key; may indicate use of compromised credentials for remote access.
PAM log confirms a login session was opened for 'phopkins' by root, indicating potentially privileged access using a valid account.
Session opened via systemd-user for 'phopkins', likely related to the same SSH session; indicates continued usage of a valid account.
Systemd-user session closed for user 'phopkins'; normal termination of session activity.
SSHD PAM session closed for user 'phopkins'; expected behavior after logout or session termination.
Outbound HTTP traffic with Debian APT User-Agent to a known Ubuntu repository; normal OS package management activity.
IDS alert from Snort matching APT package manager User-Agent; benign behavior related to system updates.
Another IDS alert from Snort with same APT signature from a different host; again, normal software update traffic.
Suricata detection of APT HTTP traffic from 10.35.33.111; normal software installation or update behavior.
Outbound HTTP connection to Ubuntu security server using APT user-agent; matches a policy rule for monitoring package management activity.
Duplicate of previous Suricata event, this time from Snort log; again indicates package manager activity, not an attack.
Another APT HTTP request to Ubuntu security mirror by a different host; not malicious but may be monitored for policy compliance.
Snort log duplicate of Suricata event; regular Ubuntu package download by package manager.
Outbound HTTP GET for Ubuntu libxml2 package from archive.ubuntu.com using Debian APT user-agent.
Snort event showing the same APT package fetch as previous; not an attack, normal behavior.
Another client fetching Ubuntu packages via APT; included for policy auditing.
Snort detection matching the same Ubuntu APT activity already seen; benign traffic.
Successful IMAP login detected for user 'samantha.thornton' from internal IP; part of normal authentication flow but may be relevant for user behavior tracking.
Repeated Dovecot authentication success; no indication of compromise, but repeated logins may be part of a pattern worth monitoring.
Authentication success for an internal user via Dovecot using plain text login; if unexpected, may indicate account compromise or lateral movement
AppArmor profile replacement detected, potentially allowing privilege or capability escalation via altered execution contexts
Repeated AppArmor profile replacement on system binary (nm-dhcp-helper), possibly to modify runtime restrictions for network configuration scripts
Profile replace operation on dhclient binary, likely part of routine system or network initialization but may also be abused for privilege escalation
SELinux/AppArmor policy replace for connman dhclient-script, possibly benign automation but indicates a system-level privilege context
Successful SSH authentication using a public key from an internal IP (10.35.35.202) to user 'phopkins'. Could indicate lateral movement or use of compromised credentials.
Login session for user 'phopkins' opened by root, confirming the successful session establishment after SSH login.
Systemd-user session opened for 'phopkins' by uid=0, reflecting successful service-level session initialization. Normal part of login flow, but relevant in context.
User 'phopkins' executed sudo for the first time to run a benign command ('tail /var/log/syslog'). While the command is non-malicious, first-time sudo usage is notable for monitoring.
A session was opened for user 'root' via sudo by user 'phopkins'. Shows privilege escalation using valid account with root access.
Normal logoff event for root user via sudo session; no signs of malicious activity.
Outbound HTTP request using Debian APT User-Agent to known Ubuntu repo; typical of legitimate system updates.
Snort alert corresponding to the same APT User-Agent outbound request; benign software update activity.
APT User-Agent HTTP request to security.ubuntu.com for package metadata; consistent with normal update checks.
Snort alert reflecting the same APT activity as above; no evidence of attack.
Another APT request to official Ubuntu PPA repository, flagged due to policy-based alert signature; expected behavior during updates.
Duplicate Snort-based alert of prior APT connection; no evidence of malicious activity.
Another Snort alert matching apt traffic to security.ubuntu.com; safe system behavior.
Suricata alert on Debian APT request to security.ubuntu.com; routine operation during system package updates.
Debian APT HTTP request to archive.ubuntu.com for package metadata; flagged due to IDS policy but benign.
APT package manager outbound connection to archive.ubuntu.com for updates; benign policy match.
HTTP GET to archive.ubuntu.com using APT user-agent, consistent with system update behavior.
Same traffic pattern as above; APT update operation using Debian APT-HTTP.
APT request to download 'bionic-updates/InRelease'; indicates scheduled or manual system update.
Duplicate detection of APT user-agent traffic reaching archive.ubuntu.com via TCP 80.
Another HTTP APT update request to bionic-updates via archive.ubuntu.com.
High-frequency detection of same signature ID; could indicate a burst of update traffic or retry loop.
APT outbound request to bionic-backports InRelease, typical of system update behavior.
Snort detection on APT user-agent connection; consistent with policy-level notification.
Final alert shows same Debian APT behavior reaching archive.ubuntu.com; no evidence of malicious behavior.
APT user-agent detected making outbound HTTP connection, typical of normal system package updates
Outbound APT HTTP request using Debian APT-HTTP user-agent, commonly seen in package management operations
APT user-agent outbound traffic flagged by IDS, consistent with routine package update checks
Repeat alert for GNU/Linux APT traffic, related to software updates, not suspicious
HTTP GET request with APT user-agent indicating system software update, typical benign traffic
User 'phopkins' successfully executed a command with sudo as root; indicates privilege escalation via sudo
Session closure log for sudo session, typical of a completed administrative action
Session opened by user 'phopkins' as root, using sudo. Valid credentials used to gain privileged access
Successful IMAP login to Dovecot using user 'meghan.morris', indicates use of valid credentials
Repeated successful login using valid account credentials via Dovecot/IMAP by 'meghan.morris'
Repeated successful Dovecot logins for user 'meghan.morris' using plaintext method (PLAIN) from the same IP. This could indicate valid credentials are being used by an unauthorized party.
tools: Hydra (if brute forced before gaining access)

description: Same user (meghan.morris) logged in successfully again from the same IP with a different log location. This log duplication suggests excessive reuse of valid credentials.
Successful login for meghan.morris from same host/IP in short succession. Same credentials used repeatedly with different process IDs, suggesting session reinitialization or automated login attempts.
Authentication success for same user and same IP across system log. Appears redundant but confirms multiple subsystem reporting same event, adding evidence for sustained access.
User 'meghan.morris' successfully authenticates from the same IP, same timestamp, with slight variation in session/process IDs. Indicates possible automation or session cycling.
Multiple successful logins from same user and IP with different session IDs. Correlation with other identical logins raises suspicion of scripted or malicious reuse.
Dovecot auth success from same user/IP with reused session ID across different log locations. Suggests session replay or mirrored logging from multiple subsystems.
Successful login via Dovecot with session replay characteristics. Same timestamp and session ID, logged from different log source. May indicate abnormal user behavior or replay.
User authenticated successfully at the same time as others, but with a different process/session ID. Appears part of a coordinated login pattern.
tools: Email clients with multiple session attempts

description: Repetition of login for same user and IP across multiple logs and sessions indicates either user automation or unauthorized credential reuse.
Successful IMAP login using plain authentication for user 'daniel.morgan' from internal IP. High number of firedtimes may suggest account abuse or scripted login.
Repeated login success for same user and IP within same second, potentially indicating scripted or automated access.
Another duplicate of successful login at the same timestamp as previous logs, suggesting burst of automated logins.
Repeated login log showing same user and IP; evidence of scripted login behavior.
Multiple successful login entries from same user and IP in very short time span; may indicate credential abuse.
Same pattern of successful logins via IMAP from the same IP and account, appearing frequently; abnormal behavior.
Successful login for same user one second later than previous logs; persistent activity within short timeframe.
Another duplicate IMAP login entry for user 'daniel.morgan' from same IP, with changing session ID, showing automation.
Log showing continued successful logins in rapid succession, suggesting possible misuse of a compromised account.
Final observed login for same account in burst of activity; total pattern suggests scripted or malicious usage.
